Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: The "install-tabs" no longer work" (#9637) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

Clicking between the installation tabs (e.g. ".NET CLI", "Package Manager", "PackageReference", "Paket CLI", "Script & Interactive", and "Cake") doesn't do anything anymore.
The displayed "tabpanel" remains being the ".NET CLI", it doesn't change.

### Repro Steps

1. You can use any package page, for example: https://www.nuget.org/packages/newtonsoft.json/
2. Click the "Package Manager" tab.
3. The tab panel remains being "> dotnet add package Newtonsoft.Json --version 13.0.3"

### Expected Behavior

The expected behavior is that the tab panel should display "NuGet\Install-Package Newtonsoft.Json -Version 13.0.3" when clicking the "Package Manager" tab.

### Screenshots

![issue](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/8082549/67e7a5df-e77f-4668-b17a-02b13849c587)

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Update FAQ link in footer" (#9641) at NuGet/NuGetGallery

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Fix Update-Database.ps1 to work on DevBox" (#9640) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
On DevBox, global packages folder location is overridden using NUGET_PACKAGES environment variable. This currently breaks the Update-Database.ps1 script, which assumes GPF is at the default location: %userprofile%\.nuget\packages.

NuGet Client docs: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/managing-the-global-packages-and-cache-folders

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add dates when a package became deprecated" (#9638) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Other/NA

### The Elevator Pitch

For the NuGet API, it would be wonderful to have a way to see when packages were marked as deprecated. We're building an open-source scanner for EOL packges/software in container images at https://github.com/xeol-io/xeol and we'd like to be able to know when packages have been marked as EOL so that users seeing results can see how long a package has been deprecated for, and make an intelligent decision about what to do in response. 

### Additional Context and Details

Related Issue: https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/7420

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

Clicking between the installation tabs (e.g. ".NET CLI", "Package Manager", "PackageReference", "Paket CLI", "Script & Interactive", and "Cake") doesn't do anything anymore.
The displayed "tabpanel" remains being the ".NET CLI", it doesn't change.

1. You can use any package page, for example: https://www.nuget.org/packages/newtonsoft.json/

The expected behavior is that the tab panel should display "NuGet\Install-Package Newtonsoft.Json -Version 13.0.3" when clicking the "Package Manager" tab.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Usability]Search Results are difficult to navigate" (#9608) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copies from: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1853049/

Steps to reproduce:
Task 7: Search for packages

BL1 Details:
Device Type: Windows 11 Professional Version 22H2 (OS Build 22621.1555), Chrome Version 114.0.5735.110
Screen Reader: JAWS Professional Edition Version 2023.2212.23

BL2 Details:
Device Type: Windows 11 Home Version 22H2 (OS Build 22621.1848), Microsoft Edge version 116.0.1908.0
Screen Reader: NVDA version 2023.1

Issue Details:
Participant was uncertain where second result started. He stated that these results would be better in a tabular form.
Participant stated that each search result should be a heading, which would allow her to navigate to each result easily.

Recommendation:
Consider showing results in a table that would allow the advantages of table navigation for screen reader users.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Usability]Package Details Tabs read as collapsed" (#9607) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1853052/

Steps to reproduce:
Task 8: View package details

BL1 Details:
Device Type: Windows 11 Professional Version 22H2 (OS Build 22621.1555), Chrome Version 114.0.5735.110
Screen Reader: JAWS Professional Edition Version 2023.2212.23

BL2 Details:
Device Type: Windows 11 Home Version 22H2 (OS Build 22621.1848), Microsoft Edge version 116.0.1908.0
Screen Reader: NVDA version 2023.1

Issue Details:
Participant doesn’t like the fact that all the tabs, except Readme, are collapsed even when selected.
Participant noted that the tabs read as “collapsed” when selected

Recommendation:
Consider by default, expanding a tab’s content when that tab is selected.

Opened issue "dotnet CLI produces extraneous modifications when updating support packages in multitarget project" (#12864) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

8.0.100-preview.7.23376.3

### Worked before?

unknown; also broken in .NET 7 and .NET 6 SDKs

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Given the following csproj:

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>net6.0;net7.0;net8.0;net472;net48</TargetFrameworks>
    <RootNamespace>nunit_test</RootNamespace>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>

    <IsPackable>false</IsPackable>
    <LangVersion>latest</LangVersion>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.NET.Test.Sdk" Version="17.6.0" />
    <PackageReference Include="NUnit" Version="3.13.3" />
    <PackageReference Include="NUnit3TestAdapter" Version="4.2.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="NUnit.Analyzers" Version="3.6.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="coverlet.collector" Version="6.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

run:

```shell
dotnet add package NUnit.Analyzers
```

Expected output:

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>net6.0;net7.0;net8.0;net472;net48</TargetFrameworks>
    <RootNamespace>nunit_test</RootNamespace>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>

    <IsPackable>false</IsPackable>
    <LangVersion>latest</LangVersion>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.NET.Test.Sdk" Version="17.6.0" />
    <PackageReference Include="NUnit" Version="3.13.3" />
    <PackageReference Include="NUnit3TestAdapter" Version="4.2.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="NUnit.Analyzers" Version="3.6.1">
      <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
      <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
    </PackageReference>
    <PackageReference Include="coverlet.collector" Version="6.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

Actual output:

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>net6.0;net7.0;net8.0;net472;net48</TargetFrameworks>
    <RootNamespace>nunit_test</RootNamespace>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>

    <IsPackable>false</IsPackable>
    <LangVersion>latest</LangVersion>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.NET.Test.Sdk" Version="17.6.0" />
    <PackageReference Include="NUnit" Version="3.13.3" />
    <PackageReference Include="NUnit3TestAdapter" Version="4.2.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="NUnit.Analyzers" Version="3.6.1">
      <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
      <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
      <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
      <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
      <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
      <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
      <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
      <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
      <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
      <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
    </PackageReference>
    <PackageReference Include="coverlet.collector" Version="6.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```


### Verbose Logs

```shell
Determining projects to restore...
  Writing C:\Users\yaakov.smith\AppData\Local\Temp\tmp2eyegs.tmp
info : X.509 certificate chain validation will use the default trust store selected by .NET for code signing.
info : X.509 certificate chain validation will use the default trust store selected by .NET for timestamping.
info : Adding PackageReference for package 'NUnit.Analyzers' into project 'C:\Temp\nunit-test\repro\repro.csproj'.
info :   GET https://api.nuget.org/v3/registration5-gz-semver2/nunit.analyzers/index.json
info :   OK https://api.nuget.org/v3/registration5-gz-semver2/nunit.analyzers/index.json 200ms
info : Restoring packages for C:\Temp\nunit-test\repro\repro.csproj...
info :   GET https://api.nuget.org/v3/vulnerabilities/index.json
info :   OK https://api.nuget.org/v3/vulnerabilities/index.json 63ms
info :   GET https://api.nuget.org/v3/vulnerabilities/vulnerability.base.json
info :   GET https://api.nuget.org/v3/vulnerabilities/vulnerability.update.json
info :   OK https://api.nuget.org/v3/vulnerabilities/vulnerability.base.json 18ms
info :   OK https://api.nuget.org/v3/vulnerabilities/vulnerability.update.json 33ms
info : Package 'NUnit.Analyzers' is compatible with all the specified frameworks in project 'C:\Temp\nunit-test\repro\repro.csproj'.
info : PackageReference for package 'NUnit.Analyzers' version '3.6.1' updated in file 'C:\Temp\nunit-test\repro\repro.csproj'.
info : PackageReference for package 'NUnit.Analyzers' version '3.6.1' updated in file 'C:\Temp\nunit-test\repro\repro.csproj'.
info : PackageReference for package 'NUnit.Analyzers' version '3.6.1' updated in file 'C:\Temp\nunit-test\repro\repro.csproj'.
info : PackageReference for package 'NUnit.Analyzers' version '3.6.1' updated in file 'C:\Temp\nunit-test\repro\repro.csproj'.
info : PackageReference for package 'NUnit.Analyzers' version '3.6.1' updated in file 'C:\Temp\nunit-test\repro\repro.csproj'.

```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Show vulnerabilities in transitive packages for PackageReference type projects in PMUI" (#8756) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
A developer should be able to see a package vulnerability indicator for any known vulnerability in a transitive package in their dependency graph. 95% of vulnerable dependencies are transitive ones and we should bring awareness to this to help the ecosystem shift left.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1288848/227604740-62e1751a-4776-4965-94ed-b8922ac82776.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add an API for checking vulnerability during packages.config restore" (#12852) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Child of https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12307

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "restore: Received an unexpected EOF or 0 bytes from the transport stream" (#9020) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

product used (mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/sdk:3.1-buster):

dotnet.exe --version:
```
   docker run --rm mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/sdk:3.1-buster dotnet --version
   3.1.100
```
OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):
```   
   docker-desktop on windows 10 
   OS Name:                   Microsoft Windows 10 Pro Insider Preview
   OS Version:                10.0.19536 N/A Build 19536

```
## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

restore a project from a solution with a big number of nuget packages and projects (>50 project), no issues for smaller solutions.

## Other suggested things
this works with `--disable-parallel` flag but it takes >20min to complete 

### Logs
[normal verbosity -v:n](https://gist.github.com/obeyda/8eb5e5df3b432ac4537cc3401159a2bc)
[diag verbosity -v:d](https://gist.github.com/obeyda/38e44ce028c200d64854531cfad2495f)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Opt-out of "HTTPS everywhere" : do not warn for HTTP sources when http sources are used in push/delete operations" (#12789) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When `allowInsecureConnections` property in packageSources section is set to true in NuGet.Config files, suppress warnings for HTTP sources when http sources are used in push/delete operations.

The PR enable the HTTP warnings in this scenario is: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/4552

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Solution Explorer info bar that warns of vulnerabilities persists after vulnerable package is uninstalled" (#12862) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

latest in dev

### Worked before?

N/A

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

Repro:
1. Create or open a project or solution, such as a .NET 7.0 Console App.
2. Right click project and click Manage NuGet Packages
3. On Browse tab, search for vulnerable package such as NewtsonSoft.Json version 6.0.x
4. Click Install
5. Note: Warning shows in Solution Explorer saying there's a package vulnerability.
6. Now uninstall the vulnerable package.

Expected:
Info bar warning goes away in Solution Explorer

Actual:
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/10777837/eb1c5901-c56b-465b-8141-bfd14354c3ce)

Warning message on Solution Explorer persists even after vulnerable package has been uninstalled.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Paulnsac patch 8" (#12860) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: ~P

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The Microsoft author-signing certificate will be updated as soon as August 14th, 2023" (#70) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current Microsoft author-signing certificate will be updated as soon as August 14th, 2023.  If you validate that packages are author signed by Microsoft using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages) or the [`verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, you will need to take steps to avoid disruptions when installing Microsoft packages signed with the new certificate.

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blog post on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/microsoft-author-signing-certificate-update-2023/

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The Microsoft author signing certificate will be updated as soon as November 1st, 2020" (#47) at NuGet/Announcements
Opened issue "Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2023-29337 | NuGet Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability" (#69) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: # Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2023-29337 | NuGet Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in .NET and NuGet on Linux. This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A vulnerability exists in .NET 6.0, .NET 7.0 and NuGet(nuget.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement) where a potential race condition that can lead to a symlink attack on Linux. Non-Linux platforms are not affected. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12653 ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## Affected software This issue only affects Linux systems. ### NuGet & NuGet Packages - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.6.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.5.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.4.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.3.2 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.2.3 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.0.4 version or earlier. [GitHub Advisory](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/security/advisories/GHSA-6qmf-mmc7-6c2p) ### .NET SDK(s) - Any .NET SDK 7.0.106 or earlier, or 7.0.303 or earlier - Any .NET SDK 6.0.117 or earlier, or 6.0.312 or earlier, or 6.0.409 or earlier. ### How do I know if I am affected? If you have a NuGet package or .NET SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-software), you're exposed to the vulnerability. ### How do I fix the issue? To fix the issue, please install the latest version of .NET 6.0 or .NET 7.0 and NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.PackageManagement versions). If you have installed one or more .NET SDKs through Visual Studio, Visual Studio will prompt you to update Visual Studio, which will also update your .NET SDKs. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.6.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.6.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.6.1/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.5.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.5.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.5.1/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.4.1 or lower, you should download and install 6.4.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.4.2/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.3.2 or lower, you should download and install 6.3.3 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.3.3/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.2.3 or lower, you should download and install 6.2.4 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.2.4/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.0.4 or lower, you should download and install 6.0.5 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.0.5/nuget.exe. You can get the version of NuGet.exe by running the `nuget` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` NuGet Version: 6.0.0.280 usage: NuGet [args] [options] Type 'NuGet help ' for help on a specific command. To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://www.nuget.org/downloads ``` You can list the versions you have installed by running the `dotnet --info` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` .NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 6.0.300 Commit: 8473146e7d Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.18363 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.300\ Host (useful for support): Version: 6.0.5 Commit: 8473146e7d .NET Core SDKs installed: 6.0.300 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk] .NET Core runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download ``` - If you're using .NET 7.0, you should download and install Runtime 7.0.7 or SDK 7.0.107 or SDK 7.0.304 from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/7.0. - If you're using .NET 6.0, you should download and install Runtime 6.0.18 or SDK 6.0.118 or SDK 6.0.312 from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/6.0. Once you have installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. Additionally, if you've deployed self-contained applications targeting any of the impacted versions, these applications are also vulnerable and must be recompiled and redeployed. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET 6.0 or .NET 7.0, please email details to secure@microsoft.com. Reports may qualify for the Microsoft .NET Core & .NET 5 Bounty. Details of the Microsoft .NET Bounty Program including terms and conditions are at . ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET GitHub organization. The main repo is located at https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client . The Announcements repo will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind. Microsoft disclaims all warranties, either express or implied, including the warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers be liable for any damages whatsoever including direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, loss of business profits or special damages, even if Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers have been advised of the possibility of such damages. Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### Acknowledgements [Kalle Niemitalo](https://github.com/KalleOlaviNiemitalo) ### External Links [CVE 2023-29337](https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2023-29337) ### Revisions V1.0 (June 13, 2023): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2023-06-13_
